learning_objectives: Understand the difference between opaque, transparent, and translucent objects.
Explain how shadows are formed and what conditions are necessary.
Describe the working of a pin-hole camera and its relation to light traveling in straight lines.
Apply the concept of light and shadows to real-life scenarios like shadow puppets and sundials.
key_concepts: Opaque objects block light completely, forming shadows.
Transparent objects allow light to pass through, forming no shadows.
Translucent objects allow some light to pass through, forming faint shadows.
A pin-hole camera works because light travels in straight lines.
variables_to_simulate: Distance between light source and object (slider)

simulation_logic.visual: Object appears on screen with corresponding properties (e.g., opaque object blocks light).

simulation_logic.description: User adjusts light intensity slider. Brighter light increases shadow contrast.
simulation_logic.visual: Light rays become more or less intense, affecting shadow darkness.

simulation_logic.description: User moves the object closer/farther from the light source. Shadow size changes.
simulation_logic.visual: Shadow on screen grows or shrinks based on distance.

simulation_logic.description: User moves the screen closer/farther from the object. Shadow sharpness changes.
simulation_logic.visual: Shadow edges become sharper or blurrier.

simulation_logic.description: User toggles pin-hole camera mode. A small hole appears, projecting an inverted image.
simulation_logic.visual: Light passes through the hole, forming an upside-down image on the screen.

mobile_ui_plan.content: Interactive canvas showing light source, object, and shadow/screen.
Short text prompts guiding the user.

misconceptions_to_address: Shadows are always black (they can be gray).
Transparent objects can form shadows (they cannot).
Pin-hole cameras produce upright images (they produce inverted images).
Shadow size depends only on object size (it also depends on light distance).
text_instructions_for_students: 1. Choose an object type and see how it affects the shadow.
2. Adjust the light intensity to observe changes in shadow darkness.
3. Move the object or screen to see how shadow size and sharpness change.
4. Try the pin-hole camera mode to see how light creates an image.
5. Answer the quiz questions to test your understanding!
safety_constraints: No flashing lights (to avoid triggering photosensitivity).
Clear labels for all interactive elements.
Responsive design for mobile screens (no horizontal scrolling).
